Graphical abstract The Li22Sn5 alloy provides abundant lithiophilic sites to enhance adsorption ability with lithium and Li2S/Li2Se ensures lower Li diffusion energy barrier for quick Li+ transfer, leading to uniform Li nucleation and deposition. Lithium metal has gained extensive attention as the most ideal candidate for next-generation battery anode owing to the ultrahigh specific capacity and the lowest electrochemical potential. However, uncontrollable dendrite growth and huge volume variation extremely restrict the future deployment of lithium metal batteries. Herein, we report metal chalcogenide SnSSe with unique nanoplate stacking structure as a robust substrate for stable Li metal anode. During the initial Li plating process, lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se sites are obtained via in-situ electrochemical reaction of Li metal and SnSSe. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation demonstrates that the formed Li2S/Li2Se achieves low Li diffusion energy barrier, ensuring rapid Li+ migration. Li22Sn5 alloy provides strong nucleation sites, promoting uniform Li nucleation. Furthermore, in-situ optical microscopy analysis suggests that the synthesized effect fundamentally inhibits lithium dendrite growth. Consequently, SnSSe modified Cu foil delivered an ultralow nucleation overpotential, superior cycling stability with 450 cycles (Coulombic efficiency, >98%), and excellent plating/stripping behavior over 2200 h at 0.5 mA cm−2. Moreover, the brilliant reversible cycles and rate capability were also realized in Li@SnSSe//LiFePO4 (LFP) full cell, shedding light on the feasibility of SnSSe for stable and dendrite-free lithium metal anode. Keywords Lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy High Li-ion conductive Li2S/Li2Se Low nucleation barrier High Coulombic efficiency Dendrite-free Li 1 Introduction Lithium metal is regarded as the most optimal choice for next-generation high-energy–density rechargeable batteries relying on its highest theoretical capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and the most negative redox potential (−3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) [1–4]. Nevertheless, uneven Li deposition can cause the uncontrollable dendrite growth and dramatic volume expansion [5,6]. Meanwhile, the unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) subsequently ruptures and forms by the constant reaction of high-reactivity Li and electrolyte during repeated Li plating/stripping process, leading to irreversible depletion of active Li, low Coulombic efficiency (CE), and catastrophic safety hazards [7,8]. All these intractable problems chronically suppress the development momentum and practical application of Li metal batteries. To date, consecutive attempts have been reasonably committed to tackling these issues for enhancing stability and reversibility of Li metal anode, such as optimizing suitable electrolyte additives for robust protective films [9,10], designing artificial SEI construction [11,12], modifying functional separators [13,14], and constructing gel-polymer/solid-state electrolytes [15–18]. Although these methods can delay the growth of dendrites to some degree, limited lithiophilic active sites bring relatively high Li nucleation overpotential. In addition, various conductive three-dimensional (3D) collectors with large pore volume and surface area (i.e., Cu/Ni foams) are also introduced to control the growth of lithium dendrites by reducing the local current density and adjusting the electric field distribution [19–23]. However, two shortcomings limit its performance. Firstly, the relatively large specific surface area and pore structure cause inevitable side reactions and excessive disordered deposition of lithium [24,25]. Secondly, the high nucleation barrier of Li on Cu/Ni foams severely restricts conformal nucleation due to typical lithiophobic nature of bare Cu/Ni foams, consequently accelerating the growth of lithium dendrites [26,27]. Therefore, some lithiophilic active sites are introduced, such as ZnO [28,29], CuO [30,31], SnO2 [32], V2O5 [33], and NiO [34,35]. Essentially, these metal oxides generally have poor electrical conductivity and cannot meet the fast lithium deposition kinetics during long-term cycling, resulting in large voltage hysteresis. Therefore, it is necessary to design the ideal material with multiple advantages including sufficient lithiophilic sites and superior electron/ion conductivity to ensure uniform Li nucleation/growth. Metal chalcogenide SnSSe has been used as a high-capacity anode for lithium-ion battery. Excellent electrochemical performance can be attributed to the integration of sulfide and selenium compounds as well as unique nanoplate stacking structure that provide better conductivity to promote the transport rate of Li+, thus effectively enhancing the electrochemical kinetics. Meanwhile, SnSSe can be converted into Li x Sn alloy and high Li-ion conductive Li2S/Li2Se by the gradual lithiation of conversion and alloying reactions (Li x SnSSe → Sn + Li2S + Li2Se → Li x Sn) [36,37]. Motivated by this finding, metal chalcogenide SnSSe may be a promising electrode material for Li metal anode to acquire high Coulombic efficiency and stable cycle behavior. Herein, metal chalcogenide SnSSe with unique nanoplate stacking structure was obtained via a one-step vacuum solid-phase reaction as lithiophilic substrate to enable dendrite-free Li deposition. The uniform Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se sites can be formed after lithiation, which can provide abundant nucleation sites for lithium deposition and low Li diffusion energy barrier for quick Li+ transfer. Benefitting from the synergistic action, in-situ optical microscopy also proves successful suppression of lithium dendrite. As a result, a dendrite-free morphology, high Coulombic efficiency over 450 cycles, and long cycling lifespan up to 2200 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 were achieved. More importantly, Li@SnSSe//LiFePO4 (LFP) full cell also exhibited remarkable superiorities, meaning the great potential of SnSSe as a stable substrate for high-energy–density lithium metal batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of SnSSe The SnSSe samples were prepared via a simple vacuum solid-state method. Briefly, Tin (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%), sulfur (Alfa Aesar, 99.5%), and selenium (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%) were mixed together at a molar ratio of 1:1:1, and then the mixture was reacted at 400 °C for 50 h with relatively rapid heating and cooling procedures (heating rate: 15 °C min−1) in a vacuum quartz tube. 2.2 Material characterizations The morphology characterizations of the as-prepared products were tested by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, TESCAN MIRA3 LMH). As for Li-deposited Cu and SnSSe modified Cu foil, the cells were disassembled in an Ar-filled glove box, followed by washing with DME solvent. The microstructure, high-resolution lattice of SnSSe and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) mapping analysis were obtained using transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100F). The crystal structures of SnSSe before and after lithiation were determined by an X-ray diffraction (XRD-6100) spectrometer with Cu-K α radiation (Shimadzu, Japan). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a K-Alpha ESCALAB 250Xi instrument (ThermoFisher-VG Scientifc, USA) with Al K α radiation as the excitation source to investigate the structure composition. 2.3 Electrochemical characterization The working electrodes were composed of active material (SnSSe) and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) as binder in a weight ratio of 90:10 using N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) as solvent, which were then magnetically stirred for 8 h to obtain the homogeneous slurry. The as-obtained slurry was cast onto Cu foil and dried at 80 °C overnight in a vacuum oven. The mass loading of the active material was about 3.4 mg cm−2. Typically, the CR2032-typed coin cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glove box (H2O< 0.5 ppm and O2< 0.5 ppm). The electrolyte was 1 M lithium bis-(trifluoromethane)sulfonimide (LiTFSI) dissolved in 1,3-dioxolane/1,2-dimethoxyethane (DOL/DME, 1:1 v/v) with 2 wt% LiNO3 as additive. The liquid electrolyte was added with a fixed amount of 50 µL in each cell. Li metal disk and celgard 2400 polypropylene membrane were utilized as the counter electrode and separator, respectively. All the batteries were measured on a LAND-CT2001A cell test system (LANDTE Co., China) at room temperature. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was analyzed on an electrochemical station (IVIUM Technologies BV, Vertex. One. EIS). Prior to the test, the cells were activated between 0.01–1 V for 5 cycles to construct a stable SEI layer. For CE test, 0.5 mAh cm−2 Li was pre-plated on the electrodes at 0.5 mA cm−2, followed by stripping to 1 V. The CE was also tested under a higher areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 and 2 mAh cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2. For the long-term cycling stability test, 3 mAh cm−2 Li was pre-plated on the SnSSe modified Cu foil and Cu at 0.5 mA cm−2, followed by repeated Li plating and stripping at 1 mA cm−2 for 1 mAh cm−2 and 2 mAh cm−2. Overpotential rate was also performed at 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 mA cm−2 with a fixed capacity of Li (1 mAh cm−2). For full cell tests, the commercial LiFePO4 (LFP) was chosen as cathode material. LiFePO4 power, Super P, and polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) with a mass ratio of 8:1:1 were mixed in Nmethyl-2-pyrolidone (NMP) solvent, followed by magnetic stirring for 12 h at room temperature, which was then coated onto aluminum foil and dried at 80 °C overnight. The areal loading of LFP is about 3.5 mg cm−2 and 10 mg cm−2. The full cells were cycled in the voltage window of 2.4–4.2 V. 2.4 Theoretical calculations The CASTEP is carried out to conduct theoretical calculations using ab initio density-functional theory [38]. For all calculations, the cut-off of the wave function is 900 eV. The energy and force convergence criteria are 10−5 eV and 0.002 eV Å−1. For the model of Li diffusion on (111) lattice plane of Li2S, (111) lattice plane of Li2Se, and (422) lattice plane of Li22Sn5, vacuum layers are 10, 10, and 12 Å, respectively. The calculations for electronic structures and the nudged elastic band are performed with (1 × 1 × 1) cell for both k-point mesh of 9 × 9 × 1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of SnSSe The SnSSe samples were fabricated through a straightforward vacuum solid-state reaction using stoichiometric tin, sulfur, and selenium powders, which were homogeneously mixed before vacuum packaging. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), the SnSSe retains a typical nanoplate stacking structure. Moreover, TEM image is further characterized to indicate individual nanoplate structure, which can provide abundant active surface area for Li nucleation and deposition (Fig. 1b). High-resolution TEM further validates that the marked two lattice intervals of 0.324 and 0.289 nm can be assigned to the (010) and (011) crystal planes of SnSSe, respectively, consistent with the values in previous literature reports (Fig. 1c) [39]. Simultaneously, the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern suggests that the SnSSe are crystalline and elemental mapping analysis is depicted in Fig. 1(d). Sn, Se, and S elements are homogeneously distributed throughout the whole nanoplate. The EDS in Fig. 1(e) further confirms the pure phase formation of SnSSe that contains only three elements of Sn, S, and Se with an atomic ratio of 34.1:31.4:34.5. XRD is also measured to affirm the crystal phase structure of SnSSe. As presented in Fig. 1(f), the diffraction peaks located at 14.6°, 27.6°, 31.4°, 40.8°, 44.9°, 48.8°, 51.2°, and 53.5° can be assigned to the (001), (010), (011), (012), (003), (110), (111), and (103) crystal planes, respectively. The schematic diagram of crystal structure of SnSSe in Fig. 1(g) displays a layered structure along the c and b axes, which will facilitate the Li+ intercalation. Besides, SnS2, SnS, and SnSe2 have also been successfully prepared in the same procedure as control samples to highlight the unique advantages of SnSSe and all the relevant characteristics are shown in Figs. S1–S3. All XRD peaks are consistent with SnS2 (JCPDS No. 23–0677), SnS (JSPDS No. 39–0354), and SnSe2 (JSPDS No. 23–0602), demonstrating the successful preparation of these materials. XPS was conducted to further analyze the surface composition and chemical status of SnSSe. According to Fig. S4(a), Sn, Se, and S elements have been detected in the XPS general survey spectrum. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Sn 3d contains two peaks located at 486.4 and 494.6 eV, matched to the binding energy of Sn 3d 5/2 and Sn 3d 3/2, respectively, indicating a valence state of Sn4+ (Fig. S4b) [40,41]. In Fig. S4(c), two peaks at 161.1 and 162.5 eV of S 2p can be ascribed to the 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 of S2−, and the peak at 165.7 eV may come from the oxidation of S2− in air. The fitted Se 3d XPS spectrum consists of two peaks shown by Se 3d 5/2 and Se 3d 3/2 of Se2− at 54.1 and 55.5 eV, corresponding to a valence state of Se2− (Fig. S4d) [42,43]. 3.2 Lithium deposition mechanism of SnSSe The initial Li deposition behavior on different electrodes makes a great influence on the subsequent Li growth. For this mater, two-electrode cell with SnSSe modified Cu foil as working electrode and Li foil as counter/reference electrode was assembled to study the initial Li deposition behavior. Fig. S5 shows the voltage-capacity curves of SnSSe modified Cu foil and bare Cu after deposition of 0.5 mAh cm−2 Li, revealing an obvious divergence between two electrodes during the Li plating process. The Li metal nucleation overpotential is defined as the difference between the bottom of the voltage dip and the flat part of voltage plateau [44]. Therefore, the Li nucleation overpotential of bare Cu is measured to be approximately 24 mV. In sharp contrast, the nucleation overpotential of SnSSe substrate is almost zero without nucleation hindrance. At the voltage above 0 V, the conversion and alloying reactions occur between deposited Li and SnSSe [45], while Li starts to nucleate and deposit on the SnSSe substrate after the voltage decreases to below 0 V. To verify the essential understanding of lithium nucleation behavior on SnSSe substrate, the ex-situ XRD characterization is performed to investigate the phase components change. As indicated in Fig. 2 (a), when the discharge voltage reaches 0.01 V, the distinct peaks of SnSSe disappear, while Li2S (JSPDS No. 26–1188), Li2Se (JSPDS No. 47–1696), and Li22Sn5 (JSPDS No. 18–0753) phases emerge, indicating the conversion and alloying reactions have occurred between SnSSe and Li. Moreover, high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) characterization evidently strengthens the above conclusions. As demonstrated, the lattice fringes of 0.33 and 0.345 nm are in accordance with the (111) crystal planes of antifluorite Li2S and Li2Se, respectively (Fig. 2b). Meanwhile, the lattice fringe of 0.402 nm is consistent with the (422) crystal plane of Li22Sn5 (Fig. 2c). Furthermore, the characteristic peaks of Li2Se, Li2S, and Li22Sn5 alloy are also accurately detected by XPS spectra (Fig. S6), meaning the positive effect of stabilizing the SEI layer on suppressing lithium dendrites. Accompanying with the amount of lithium deposition to 3 mAh cm−2, the characteristic peaks of Li2S, Li2Se, and Li22Sn5 are still detected in the XRD pattern (Fig. S7). Moreover, when the cut-off voltage is charged to 1 V during the stripping process, the three phases are still remained (Fig. S8), indicating their stability. These results suggest that the lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se sites can keep the function of continuously inducing uniform lithium nucleation/deposition and fast Li+ transfer during cycling process. To illustrate the superiority between Li2S, Li2Se, and Li22Sn5 alloy, density functional theory (DFT) calculation was employed to compare the Li diffusion energy barrier of Li2S, Li2Se, and Li22Sn5 along different directions of [111], [111], and [422], respectively. The computational models and the corresponding lithium atom migration paths on the above-mentioned substances are exhibited in Fig. 2(d–f). The calculation results show that the diffusion energy barriers of Li2Se, Li2S, and Li22Sn5 are 1.28, 1.34, and 1.44 eV, respectively (Fig. 2g–i), indicating that Li easily diffuses into Li2Se and Li2S. Therefore, it can be proved that Li2Se and Li2S have the ability to improve lithium ionic conductivity, which means that lithium ions are uniformly distributed and the generation of lithium dendrites can be suppressed. Based on the above results, the schematic of distinct Li nucleation and growth on SnSSe modified Cu foil and bare Cu is illustrated in Fig. 3 (a and b). At the initial Li plating process, SnSSe is firstly subjected to conversion and alloying reactions to form Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se. The lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy effectively reduces nucleation overpotential and guides uniform Li deposition. Meanwhile, the as-formed Li2S/Li2Se sites with high ion-conductivity promote homogenization of lithium-ion flux as well. During the subsequent deposition process, lithium can grow uniformly on this integrated substrate, suppressing the formation of dendrites. However, the random and inhomogeneous Li nucleation inevitably aggravates the growth of Li dendrites due to the lack of nucleation sites on the surface of bare Cu. To visually verify the profound influence of SnSSe on the inhibition of dendritic growth, the morphological evolutions of Li deposition on SnSSe modified Cu foil and bare Cu were first monitored through an in-situ optical microscope at 2 mA cm−2 in Fig. 3(c). As displayed in Fig. 3(d and e), in the initial state, both electrodes show the clean and flat surface. SnSSe can guarantee the uniform and smooth deposition of lithium even after 50 min, accompanied by a slight volume change. On the contrary, after 10 min of lithium deposition, some visible lithium nuclei were highlighted on the surface of bare Cu. When the time of lithium deposition increases from 10 to 50 min, the continuous growth of mossy and dendritic lithium can be observed. Even at a Li capacity of 2 mAh cm−2, the surface of SnSSe is still no dendrite (Fig. 3f), and only when the deposition amount reaches 3 mAh cm−2, some lithium dendrites are just observed (Fig. 3g). The dendrites on the surface of bare Cu are very serious and disorderly distributed (Fig. 3h and i). As a conclusion, the SnSSe can fruitfully inhibit the formation of lithium dendrites and stabilize the surface of lithium metal anode. To further understand the morphology evolution of Li deposition and dissolution, ex-situ SEM was carried out. As shown in Fig. 4 (a and d), when 0.5 mAh cm−2 Li is deposited on SnSSe substrate, a homogeneous morphology is observed, indicating uniform Li nucleation. Compared with the pristine state (Fig. S9), the obvious morphology change should be attributed to the formation of the SEI and the appropriate volume change after Li+ insertion. As the lithium deposition capacity increases to 1 mAh cm−2, the well-maintained surface still exists (Fig. 4b and e). Even when the amount of deposited Li increases to 3 mAh cm−2, the dense Li layer without bulk dendritic features can be captured (Fig. 4c and f). In sharp contrast, Cu surface is actually covered by uneven Li dendrites from 0.5 to 1 and 3 mAh cm−2 (Fig. S10). After the 50th plating and stripping, the SnSSe substrate retains the state of dendrite-free Li (Fig. 4g and h). However, as a control, messy Li dendrites can be visualized on the Cu surface (Fig. 4i). Meanwhile, Fig. S11 shows the cross-sectional views after 50 cycles on SnSSe modified Cu foil. The thickness of SnSSe remains at ∼17.2 μm after the 50th plating, while the thickness decreases to ∼16.8 μm after the 50th stripping, indicating the dimensional stability of the SnSSe substrate. Evidently, the SnSSe substrate can provide abundant active nucleation sites and homogenize the Li-ion flow to guide uniform Li plating/stripping, resulting in the excellent lithium deposition behavior. 3.3 Electrochemical properties of SnSSe in half-cells The CE, determined by the ratio of Li stripping capacity to plating capacity, is a key indicator to evaluate the reversibility for Li utilization. As illustrated in Fig. 5 (a), SnSSe modified Cu foil can achieve sustainable 450 cycles with an average CE of 98.2% at the current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 for 0.5 mAh cm−2 Li, which outperforms the SnS2, SnS, and SnSe2 modified Cu foil (Fig. S12). The apparent superiority can be ascribed to the ideal synergistic effect of SnSSe by inducing uniform Li nucleation and growth. As comparison, the CE of bare Cu suffers from sharp decline after 200 cycles due to the consumption of electrolyte and metal lithium. When the current density increases to 1 mA cm−2, the CE of SnSSe modified Cu foil still shows high value up to 97.6% over 200 cycles without attenuation, while bare Cu is in a state of poor CE (Fig. 5b). To compare with the performance of Sn, we prepare the Sn modified Cu foil to test electrochemical performance. The characterization of Sn nanoparticles is shown in Fig. S13. As shown in Fig. S14, Sn modified Cu foil shows the low average CE of 96.9% for less than 100 cycles and the large voltage polarization, indicating a poor electrochemical kinetics. Further increasing the current density to 2 mA cm−2, SnSSe modified Cu foil still manifests a high CE of 97.2% for 180 cycles (Fig. 5c). Inversely, the CE of Cu oscillated rapidly and dropped to below 65.7% just within 40 cycles. Impressively, even at a relatively higher deposition capacity of 2 mAh cm−2, a predominant CE upon to 150 cycles is still obtained with the SnSSe modified Cu foil (Fig. S15). Such excellent cycle stability of SnSSe modified Cu foil is mainly attributed to the formation of stable SEI and successful suppression of lithium dendrites. Lithium nucleation in the first discharge cycle is employed to reveal the nucleation and growth process. As shown in Fig. 5(d), SnSSe modified Cu foil exhibits a smaller lithium nucleation overpotential (only 7 mV) than that of Cu (28 mV) at 1 mA cm−2. When the current density increases to 2 mA cm−2, SnSSe still delivers a lower overpotential (10 mV) compared to bare Cu (43 mV) in Fig. S16. The reduced nucleation barrier in SnSSe substrate can be mainly attributed to the lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy. Besides, the corresponding discharge-charge profiles of SnSSe modified Cu foil and bare Cu at the 2nd and the 80th cycles are also given in Fig. 5(e), fitting well with the CE. Especially, SnSSe modified Cu foil displays a smaller voltage polarization than bare Cu in the 2nd and the 80th cycles, indicating excellent stability and improved kinetics during the Li plating/stripping process. These results clearly prove that the strong lithiophilicity of SnSSe can lead to low polarization. More importantly, EIS is conducted to further monitor the interfacial charge transfer properties of SnSSe modified Cu foil and Cu after the 50th cycle. As displayed in Nyquist plots of Fig. 5(f), SnSSe modified Cu foil exhibits a lower charge transfer resistance (R ct) (∼31.7 Ω) than that of bare Cu (∼135.9 Ω) due to the fast Li+ migration provided by Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se, implying uniform and stable interface feature. Moreover, galvanostatic cycling stability based on symmetrical cells was also tested to further explore the long-term performance. As shown in Fig. 5(g) and Fig. S17, a relatively flat cycling stability can be achieved on the SnSSe modified Cu foil with a low overpotential of 9 mV as long as 2200 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 and 0.5 mAh cm−2. When the applied current density and deposition areal capacity reach 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2, SnSSe modified Cu foil can deliver a life span of 1000 h with small overpotential (18 mV) (Fig. S18a). Accordingly, the surface composition of SnSSe modified Cu foil after 100 cycles is recorded by XRD, which proves the existence of Li2Se/Li2S and Li22Sn5 alloy (Fig. S19). Although bare Cu undergoes a comparable overpotential, an obvious fluctuating voltage profile is monitored after merely 200 h. Compared with SnSSe, SnSe2 modified Cu foil displays similar overpotential, but suffers from inferior cycle performance. In addition, SnS2 and SnS modified Cu foil encounter worse cycle performance (Fig. S20), which is sufficient to prove the synergistic merit of lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se sites. Even at a high areal capacity of 2 mAh cm−2 at 1 mA cm−2, no severe voltage oscillations on the SnSSe modified Cu foil can be recorded over 700 h (Fig. S18b). The rate capacities of symmetrical cells based on the Cu and SnSSe substrate are further investigated by changing the current densities from 0.5 to 4 mA cm−2 with a fixed areal capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 5h). Clearly, SnSSe modified Cu foil exhibits much lower overpotential than bare Cu under the same current density from the enlarged view of the curves (Fig. S21). Moreover, the gap between these two cells becomes bigger along with the increase of current densities. Such superiority of SnSSe is an evidence of the stable electrode to ensure low overpotential and uniform Li deposition. Therefore, these results again demonstrate a key advantage of SnSSe as desirable substrate. 3.4 Electrochemical properties of SnSSe in full-cells Ultimately, to further investigate the practical application of Li@SnSSe as Li metal anode, full cells composed of LFP cathode (areal loading: 3.5 mg cm−2) were assembled and tested (denoted as Li@SnSSe//LFP), with Li@Cu//LFP as comparison. Fig. 6 (a) shows the cycling stability of full cells at 1 C (1 C = 160 mA g−1). The Li@SnSSe//LFP delivers the capacity retention of 88.2% after 300 cycles. More impressively, a light-emitting diode (LED) device can be lit up by the Li@SnSSe//LFP system in the illustration, which also serves as the evidence for lithium metal batteries in practical application. In contrast, the Li@Cu//LFP suffers from a detrimental capacity fade after 150 cycles, which is mainly ascribed to inhomogeneous Li plating and accelerated consumption of electrolyte. As observed from Fig. 6(b), the corresponding charge-discharge profile of Li@SnSSe//LFP manifests the lower voltage polarization than that of Li@Cu//LFP at the 1st cycle, indicating the excellent kinetics. The rate capability in Fig. 6(c) is also obtained though gradually increasing the current density. Compared with Li@Cu//LFP, Li@SnSSe//LFP presents superior discharge capacity of 147.4, 142.3, 134.6, 125.5, and 102.6 mAh g−1 at the current rate of 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C, respectively. Even at a higher rate of 10 C, Li@SnSSe//LFP still offers the capacity of 62.8 mAh g−1. When the current density is set back to 0.2 C, the capacity returns to 144.5 mAh g−1. However, the Li@Cu//LFP undergoes rapid capacity decay as the current rate increases and only delivers a reversible capacity of 26.4 mAh g−1 at 10 C. Moreover, the voltage polarization of Li@SnSSe//LFP is lower than that of the Li@Cu//LFP, especially at 5 C (Fig. 6d and e). Furthermore, when matched with a high loading LFP cathode (areal loading: ∼10 mg cm−2), Li@SnSSe//LFP cell also achieves excellent cycling performance (Fig. S22), demonstrating the promising practicality. 4 Conclusions In summary, metal chalcogenide SnSSe synthesized by a one-step vacuum solid-phase reaction was successfully employed as a lithiophilic substrate for high-performance dendrite-free Li metal anode. During the initial Li plating process, lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se sites were obtained via in-situ electrochemical reaction of Li metal and SnSSe. DFT calculation demonstrates that Li2Se/Li2S prominently possesses low Li diffusion energy barrier, ensuring fast ion transfer kinetics, while the existence of Li22Sn5 alloy can provide strong adsorption sites for lithium nucleation and guide uniform Li deposition. As a result, a high average Coulombic efficiency of 98.2% for 450 cycles and an ultralong lifespan of 2200 h at 0.5 mA cm−2 were achieved. Moreover, the full cells assembled with LFP cathode also exhibited outstanding electrochemical performance (1 C, 300 cycles) and rate capability (0.2 to 5 C). This material illustrates a potential advantage in developing the next-generation high-performance Li metal batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium metal has gained extensive attention as the most ideal candidate for next-generation battery anode owing to the ultrahigh specific capacity and the lowest electrochemical potential. However, uncontrollable dendrite growth and huge volume variation extremely restrict the future deployment of lithium metal batteries. Herein, we report metal chalcogenide SnSSe with unique nanoplate stacking structure as a robust substrate for stable Li metal anode. During the initial Li plating process, lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy and Li2S/Li2Se sites are obtained via in-situ electrochemical reaction of Li metal and SnSSe. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation demonstrates that the formed Li2S/Li2Se achieves low Li diffusion energy barrier, ensuring rapid Li+ migration. Li22Sn5 alloy provides strong nucleation sites, promoting uniform Li nucleation. Furthermore, in-situ optical microscopy analysis suggests that the synthesized effect fundamentally inhibits lithium dendrite growth. Consequently, SnSSe modified Cu foil delivered an ultralow nucleation overpotential, superior cycling stability with 450 cycles (Coulombic efficiency, >98%), and excellent plating/stripping behavior over 2200 h at 0.5 mA cm−2. Moreover, the brilliant reversible cycles and rate capability were also realized in Li@SnSSe//LiFePO4 (LFP) full cell, shedding light on the feasibility of SnSSe for stable and dendrite-free lithium metal anode.

coredata.dc:title: In situ formation of lithiophilic Li22Sn5 alloy and high Li-ion conductive Li2S/Li2Se via metal chalcogenide SnSSe for dendrite-free Li metal anodes
